Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Determining host seeking through olfaction in the nematode Parastrongyloides trichosuri
Award.AbstractNarration:
Parasitic nematodes of humans, animals, and plants are major sources of economic loss and health-related hardship. The impact on human health alone is staggering. Current estimates suggest that nearly 1 billion people globally harbor a parasitic nematode infection. Despite their prevalence, our understanding of how parasitic nematodes find and infect their appropriate biological hosts remains poorly characterized. Olfaction is widely thought to be an important aspect of host seeking, since it is the sensory modality most likely to confer species-specificity. This project will elucidate the extent to which parasitic nematodes rely on host-emitted odors to find and infect a host. This research will be conducted at La Trobe University in Melbourne, Australia in collaboration with Dr. Warwick Grant, a global leader on nematode genetics. Dr. Grant also has unparalleled expertise with a unique parasitic nematode, Parastrongyloides trichosuri, whose native hosts are Australian possums.

Research efforts in parasitic nematodes have been hampered by an inability to develop genetically tractable model species. The goal of this project is to develop Parastrongyloides trichosuri, a parasitic nematode of the Australian possum, as a model for odor-driven host seeking and the genetic analysis of olfactory neural circuits. Among parasitic nematodes, P. trichosuri is uniquely amenable to in vitro culturing, genetic manipulation, and transgenesis. This project will focus on conducting quantitative behavioral analysis, laser and genetic ablation analysis, and calcium imaging of P. trichosuri. The project aims to gain insight into the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which parasitic nematodes locate hosts to infect. By determining the host-specific odors that promote host seeking, and the underlying neural basis for the behavior, this study will facilitate development of new strategies to combat nematode infection. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parasitic nematodes of humans, animals, and plants are major sources of economic loss and health-related hardships, yet we know very little about how they sense, discriminate, and infect their hosts. Many have hypothesized that skin-penetrating nematodes could use olfactory cues to locate and infect the appropriate host, since all animals emit unique odor blends. However, little is known about odor-driven behavior in these species, and even less is understood about the cellular and molecular mechanisms for host-seeking behavior. The focus of my research is to interrogate the contribution of olfactory neural circuits on host-seeking behavior, and to eventually develop novel strategies to combat harmful nematode infections. The goal of this project was to develop the nematode species Parastrongyloides trichosuri as a model for odor-driven host seeking, and for the genetic analysis of olfactory neural circuits.  P. trichosuri, whose native hosts are Australian brushtail possums, is exceptional among parasitic nematodes. Unlike other species that require regular passage through permissive hosts, P. trichosuri can be maintained for many free-living generations under carefully controlled laboratory conditions. This parasite is amenable to genetic approaches including crosses, transgenesis, genetic ablations, and the identification and maintenance of mutant strains, making it an ideal parasitic nematode for investigating olfactory driven host-seeking behaviors.

 

A major focus of this project was to obtain P. trichosuri cultures, learn free-living culturing techniques, and adapt the culturing protocols to resources available in the United States.  Under the direction of Dr. Warwick Grant at La Trobe University in Melbourne, Australia I was able to obtain a population of P. trichosuri from a university managed colony of Australian brushtail possums, maintain free-living P. trichosuri cultures for >20 generations, and successfully establish a free-living P. trichosuri line at my home institution, the University of California Los Angeles. A secondary focus of this project was to test the olfactory preferences of P. trichosuri at different life stages. Skin-penetrating nematodes, such as P. trichosuri, are infective only during a particular stage of their life cycle called the infective juvenile (IJ). P. trichosuri IJs were tested in quantitative chemotaxis assays and found to be attracted to a number of mammalian odorants, suggesting preliminary evidence for olfaction being critical a component of host-seeking behavior. Further analysis demonstrated that odorant responses of P. trichosuri IJs differed from closely related skin-penetrating nematodes, supporting the hypothesis that unique odorant combinations could contribute to host-specificity. I also demonstrated that free-living larvae and adult P. trichosuri are highly attracted to host fecal matter, where they are thought to reside and feed on bacteria present in the feces. By contrast, P. trichosuri IJs were moderately repelled by fecal matter, suggesting a model in which attraction to fecal odor is down regulated at the infective life stage allowing the IJs to leave the feces in search for hosts. I am now developing transgenesis, laser and genetic ablation techniques, and calcium imaging techniques to interrogate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of olfactory driven host-seeking in P. trichosuri.

 

This project, and the EAPSI program in general, also allowed me to experience academic research, science education, and science policy in Australia via collaboration with the Australian Academy of Sciences.
